text:
Prior to HBS, I
worked in finance

and focused on co-investments,
which is minority
investing in companies.

I was drawn to how HBS
is general management

and how you have to take
operations, data science;

you have to take
all these courses.

Being in a section where
40% is international

and everyone's just coming
from different sectors

outside of maybe just
finance and consulting,

I thought that those
skills and the people

and the friendships that I
would make would change my life.

I've been involved a
lot with being a Student
Advisor for the CPD office.

I felt as if being
a Student Advisor

allowed me to give
back and help students

how to create a list
of firms that satisfy

the strategy that
they're looking for,

how to network with
people while learning

about their industry
and not just for a job,

and then specifically conducting
informational interviews.

When evaluating an offer,
I would recommend meeting

with a Career Coach
because they can

see your body language, or
just changes in your voice

that maybe a close
friend or family member

can't read if you're just
relaying that information
during a phone call.

After I had several offers,
including a summer internship

offer, I met with
a Career Coach,

and the feedback that I
received was my energy

when I was reviewing the
circumstances was pretty low

and my enthusiasm
just wasn't there.

I definitely think
it's helpful to meet

with a third-party person who
can give you that information.

And then I think,
also to check the box,

12twenty has a lot of data
points about just title,
geographic location, salary.

I think my confidence has grown
by being forced to network

and reach out to firms and
ask them thoughtful questions
about their strategy.

And being able to have a
conversation with the person,

on the other hand, versus
just purely ask for a job,

it's made me realize that I have
insights and knowledge of my own
that are useful.

And then, second, being
a Student Career Advisor,

that's also built my
confidence because I realized

that I actually have a
lot of helpful advice

to give first years and
that I can be a supportive
person in their lives.

So if I was to
summarize it all up,

I would say it's
definitely been empowering.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
